tasks.title: mRNA tumor sensitization for checkpoint blockade
tasks.sourceTitle: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

tasks.title: JWST phase-curve evidence for an atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b
tasks.sourceTitle: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

tasks.title: GCSE chemistry grade 8-9 multi-step quantitative solving
tasks.sourceTitle: GCSE Chemistry topic set (AQA specification-aligned, synthesized benchmark)

critical_issues: Some evidence entries in claim_audit.json use report summaries as “quotes” (e.g., L42–L46) rather than verbatim findings; this is still grounded but could mislead downstream users expecting literal quotations.

In quantitative_findings.json (Q03), the inclusion of L49 as an evidence line reference is not directly supporting the p-value/result (it is a caveat about non-randomization). The core quantitative evidence is correctly at L30.
value.summary: Across the JSON files, the study type, cohorts (mouse n=78/84; human n=130 with 43 vaccinated/87 unvaccinated), key quantitative results (immunopeptidome 62.3% vs 37.3%; MHC-I 40.6% vs 20.6%; p=0.01 survival association; IFN score 3.1 vs 1.0; PD-L1 2.4x; CD8 density 1.8x), mechanistic narrative, and the major caveats (retrospective/non-randomized human data, timing heterogeneity, tumor-type mix, translation limits) are accurately represented without fabricated numbers or overstated causal claims

The JSON outputs accurately reflect the report’s study design (JWST/MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy), the key quantitative findings (dayside brightness temperature 342 ± 22 K; epsilon 0.19 +0.23/-0.14; Bond albedo < 0.08; CO2-band depth 96 ppm; likelihood ratio 7.4; plausible 0.3–1.0 bar CO2-rich family), and the main caveats (single-planet inference, retrieval/systematics sensitivity, weaker night-side constraints, and composition/circulation/cloud degeneracies). Claims are appropriately hedged (

outputValidation.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P02",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 1.85,
    "units": "g CO2",
    "precision_note": "Rounded to 3 significant figures to match given mass and purity data."
  },
  "method": "First find pure CaCO3 mass: 5.00 g x 0.840 = 4.20 g. Convert to moles using n = m/Mr with Mr(CaCO3) = 100.1, so n(CaCO3) = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol. From CaCO3 + 2HCl -> CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, the mole ratio CaCO3:CO2 is 1:1, so n(CO2) = 0.04196 mol. Then m(CO2) = n x Mr(CO2), and from atomic data Mr(CO2) = 12.0 + 2x16.0 = 44.0. Therefore m(CO2) = 0.04196 x 44.0 = 1.846 g, giving 1.85 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = m / Mr",
    "CaCO3 + 2HCl -> CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O",
    "m = n x Mr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L14",
    "L24",
    "L33",
    "L34"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Acid is stated to be in excess, so CaCO3 limits yield.",
    "CO2 mass is below pure CaCO3 mass, chemically reasonable."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.888,
    "units": "g Cu",
    "precision_note": "Rounded to 3 significant figures from current and time data."
  },
  "method": "Time is 30.0 min = 1800 s, so total charge passed is Q = It = 1.50 x 1800 = 2700 C. Moles of electrons are n(e-) = Q/F = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol. From Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu, two moles of electrons deposit one mole of copper, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Using Cu molar mass 63.55 g mol^-1, mass deposited is m = n x Mr = 0.01399 x 63.55 = 0.8889 g, giving 0.888 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "Q = I x t",
    "n(e-) = Q / F",
    "Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L19",
    "L24",
    "L51",
    "L52"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Time converted from minutes to seconds before charge calculation.",
    "Electron-to-copper stoichiometry of 2:1 was applied correctly."
  ]
}

critical_issues: P02 final_answer.units is "g CO2" but the expected schema/unit output is "g" (groundingValid: false, explicit validation error). This makes the JSON not practically usable downstream even though the numeric calculation is consistent with the report (L33-L36, L25-L26).

P05 final_answer.units is "g Cu" but the expected schema/unit output is "g" (groundingValid: false, explicit validation error). This again breaks downstream usability despite the method being consistent with the report inputs (L17-L19, L51-L53).

P01 precision is internally inconsistent: final_answer.value is given as 0.02 while the precision_note claims "Reported to 3 significant figures (0.0200)". 0.0200 is 3 s.f. but 0.02 is 1 s.f.; this is a calibration/formatting error relative to the stated significant-figure requirement (L10, L16, L29-L30).

P02 line references omit key directly-provided molar mass lines (Mr(CaCO3)=100.1 at L25 and Mr(CO2)=44.0 at L26) while the method relies on those values (it cites L24 instead). The references provided are not the most valid/traceable mapping for the quantitative claims, reducing auditability.
value.summary: The set largely follows the correct GCSE quantitative methods and uses the correct report data for calculations in P03, P04, and P06 with appropriate equations and valid line refs. However, the outputs fail strict grading because two files (P02, P05) have invalid/nonconforming units explicitly flagged by validation, which harms downstream practical use, and P01 has a significant-figures inconsistency between the numeric value and its stated precision. value.summary: Across all JSON files, the outputs accurately reflect the report’s study design (preclinical mouse + retrospective human cohort), main mechanistic claims (type I IFN-driven antigen presentation changes and PD-L1 upregulation), quantitative findings (all reported percentages/fold-changes/p-value), and key control/conditional results (vehicle/ICI-only limits, lipid particle control null, IFNAR1 blockade eliminating benefit). The human evidence is appropriately framed as retrospective/associational

critical_issues: Minor calibration issue: the public-facing summary uses wording like "have discovered" while the report frames the result as evidence/suggestive rather than definitive (compare to L52-L53). This is not a quantitative fabrication, but it slightly overstates certainty.
value.summary: Overall the JSON outputs are faithful to the provided report and are practically useful for downstream review. Quantitative values (dayside brightness temperature 342 +/- 22 K, epsilon 0.19 +0.23/-0.14, Bond albedo <0.08, CO2 band depth 96 ppm, likelihood ratio 7.4, pressure scale 0.3–1.0 bar) match the report and are correctly linked to valid line references (L27–L32). The key qualitative conclusions and controls/null results are also correctly captured: the airless model’s inability to fit all

outputValidation.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P02",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 1.85,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Given to 3 significant figures matching the precision of the input mass (5.00 g) and purity percentage (84.0%)."
  },
  "method": "First, the mass of pure calcium carbonate in the limestone sample is determined by multiplying the total sample mass (5.00 g) by its purity (84.0%), yielding 4.20 g of CaCO3. Next, the moles of CaCO3 are calculated using the formula n = m / Mr, with the relative molecular mass of CaCO3 (100.1) giving approximately 0.04196 moles. According to the balanced chemical equation, the molar ratio of CaCO3 to CO2 is 1:1, meaning 0.04196 moles of CO2 will be produced. Finally, the mass of CO2 is found by multiplying its moles by its relative molecular mass (44.0), resulting in approximately 1.85 g of CO2.",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = m / Mr",
    "m = n * Mr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L25",
    "L26",
    "L33",
    "L34"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "The mass of pure CaCO3 was correctly calculated as a percentage of the total limestone mass.",
    "Stoichiometric ratio 1:1 between CaCO3 and CO2 from the balanced equation was applied correctly.",
    "Final value rounded to 3 significant figures based on the precision of the input data (5.00 g, 84.0%)."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P03",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.0702,
    "units": "mol dm-3",
    "precision_note": "Given to 3 significant figures to match the lowest precision input value, the NaOH concentration (0.150 mol dm-3)."
  },
  "method": "To find the concentration of H2SO4, we first calculate the moles of NaOH used in the titration. Using the formula c = n / V and converting the volume to dm3, the moles of NaOH is 0.150 mol dm-3 * 0.02340 dm3 = 0.00351 mol. The balanced chemical equation shows that 1 mole of H2SO4 reacts with 2 moles of NaOH, so the moles of H2SO4 is half that of NaOH, which is 0.001755 mol. Finally, the concentration of H2SO4 is calculated by dividing its moles by its volume in dm3 (0.02500 dm3), resulting in 0.0702 mol dm-3.",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = c * V",
    "c = n / V"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L15",
    "L39",
    "L40",
    "L41"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Volumes were properly converted from cm3 to dm3 before calculating moles.",
    "The 1:2 molar ratio from the balanced equation was correctly applied to find the moles of acid.",
    "Final concentration was rounded to 3 significant figures, matching the precision of the NaOH concentration."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.889,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Given to 3 significant figures, matching the precision of the current (1.50 A) and time (30.0 min)."
  },
  "method": "To calculate the mass of copper deposited, the total electric charge (Q) is first determined using the formula Q = I * t. The time is converted to seconds (30.0 min * 60 s/min = 1800 s), and multiplied by the current (1.50 A) to give 2700 C. The moles of electrons are then calculated using n(e-) = Q / F, yielding 2700 / 96500 = 0.02798 mol. The half-equation Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu indicates that 2 moles of electrons are required to deposit 1 mole of copper, meaning 0.01399 moles of Cu are formed. Finally, the mass is found by multiplying the moles by the atomic mass of copper (63.55), resulting in 0.889 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "Q = I * t",
    "n(e-) = Q / F",
    "m = n * Ar"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L17",
    "L18",
    "L51",
    "L52"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Time was correctly converted from minutes to seconds before calculating the total charge.",
    "The 2:1 molar ratio of electrons to copper atoms derived from the half-equation was applied correctly.",
    "Final mass was rounded to 3 significant figures to align with the precision of the input current and time."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P06",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.0736,
    "units": "dimensionless",
    "precision_note": "Given to 3 significant figures, matching the precision of the equilibrium moles (0.180 mol, 0.220 mol) and volume (2.00 dm3)."
  },
  "method": "To calculate the equilibrium constant Kc, we first find the equilibrium concentrations of both gases by dividing their moles by the volume of the vessel (2.00 dm3). The concentration of NO2 is 0.180 mol / 2.00 dm3 = 0.0900 mol dm-3, and the concentration of N2O4 is 0.220 mol / 2.00 dm3 = 0.110 mol dm-3. Next, these concentration values are substituted into the equilibrium expression for the reaction, which is Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]. Squaring the NO2 concentration gives 0.00810, and dividing by the N2O4 concentration yields approximately 0.0736. As instructed, the final answer is reported as dimensionless.",
  "key_equations": [
    "c = n / V",
    "Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L20",
    "L56",
    "L57",
    "L58"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Moles were converted to concentrations using the 2.00 dm3 vessel volume before plugging into the Kc expression.",
    "The concentration of NO2 was correctly squared in the numerator of the equilibrium constant formula.",
    "The final value was rounded to 3 significant figures to match the precision of the input moles and volume."
  ]
}

critical_issues: P01: The stated precision is not faithful to the provided numeric value. final_answer.value is 0.02 (which is not 3 significant figures), but the precision_note claims “Given to 3 significant figures” and the method states “0.0200 mol dm-3” (4 d.p.). This is an internal contradiction and a fabricated precision claim relative to what is actually output (L29-L30, L16).

P05: The method uses the Faraday constant (F = 96,500 C mol-1) and copper Ar = 63.55, but line_refs omit the lines where those values are defined (F at L19; Cu at L24). This makes the grounding/traceability incomplete for downstream review, contrary to the requirement that line references map to the report (L19, L24).
P06: The method and key_equations use the concentration relation c = n / V, but line_refs omit the report line that defines it (L15). This reduces auditability of the derivation (L15, L56-L59).
value.summary: Most computed final numeric values appear consistent with the report’s data and equations (P02–P06 calculations look arithmetically correct and aligned with L14–L21, L33–L59). However, the outputs do not meet strict grading requirements due to (1) a clear precision inconsistency/fabricated precision statement in P01 (value 0.02 vs claimed 3 s.f., and method stating 0.0200), and (2) multiple cases where line references do not cover key constants/equations actually used (notably P05 missing L19/L4
